ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Amazing course - CPB is THE BEST

I would recommend this course to other students. It can be a fair amount of work on a weekly basis: a decent amount of reading with a weekly reading response, and a 14-16 pg final paper at the end of term. That said, it's an extremely interesting topic and Prof. Panter-Brick is great. Hopefully the format will be changed so it's a little less student-run (Prof. Panter-Brick has lots of great insights/fieldwork experience to contribute), and it should hopefully be made a WR credit in the future, too.

Yes, highly recommended! A wonderful introduction to medical anthropology, even for non-anthropology majors. Almost all of the readings were interesting (and for the ones that were not, Prof. Panter-Brick will agree with you) and the workload was fair.
This was an introductory course with in depth discussions on Medical Anthropology and its applications. I would recommend this as a good course, namely because Professor Panter-Brick is so great!
Prof. Panter-Brick is engaging and knowledgable. Interesting and relevant course material.
Maybe, if you're interested in the topic--otherwise, you might check out during discussions.
